results.title: By design
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Collings and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: A jet plane, a boomerang, and a locomotive are shown as examples of successful design in which the right materials are used for the right purposes. Showing examples of the work of Australia’s industrial designers, the film explains that the purpose for which an article is intended determines the final design. Examples include household articles such as an electric iron, comfortable chairs, lamps, and saucepans.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Geoffrey Collings and Australian National Film Board

results.title: Buzkashi: the national game (D)
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description: WARNING: THIS FILM CONTAINS SOME VISUALLY DISTURBING IMAGES Buzkashi is the once forbidden sport performed on horseback by the tribes of Afghanistan. Buzkashi requires incredible riding ability, as the opposing teams battle for a head-less calf. the intense pride and rivalry of a tribal society, as well as the role of physical superiority and competition are implicit. No commentary - natural sound track only.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation

results.title: Buy, buy
results.brief_description: A wry examination of the nature of television commercials, our most potent advertising medium, as seen by the ad men and producers who make them. During the production of laxative and cosmetic commercials ad men voice strong opinions both justifying and condemning what they do. They are sometimes defensive, sometimes more cynical than any consumer.

results.title: Butterfly
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “1976-1980 Olympic & world class swimmers”.
One of a series of films which shows swimmers, and their styles and techniques. Slow motion is used to clarify the demonstrations. This film concentrates on butterfly swimming. Swimmers featured include Mike Bruner, Steve Gregg and Joe Bottom.

results.title: Butterflies
results.brief_description: This film studies the life history of the cabbage butterfly and the swallow-tail butterfly, showing their habits and characteristics, and their role in nature: that of aiding cross-fertilization of flowers. The cabbage butterfly’s destructiveness and its control by a natural enemy is shown.

results.title: Butt welds in sheet metal
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Gas Welding”.
Episode five in a series of nine short instructional films showing methods for oxyacetylene welding. This film demonstrates how welding on a sheet of metal and then welding with a rod are necessary steps before proceeding to butt weld two pieces of metal together.

results.title: But first - this message
results.creator_credit: Yale Marc, Jim Herzig and Action for Children's Television
results.brief_description: Presents an analysis of commercial television programs for children, with excerpts from shows and commercials. Includes comments from professionals working with children and reactions from children.

results.title: A Busy sort of bloke: Harold Hughan
results.creator_credit: Lindsay Frazer, Gillian Armstrong, Australia Council and Crafts Council of Australia
results.brief_description: The simplicity and charm of the man and his work are portrayed in this film, which shows Harold Hughan at home and at work. He is seen making a platter, and he discusses the objective of his pieces made with clay. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: The Busy harbour
results.brief_description: Ted and Maria visit a tugboat captain in the busy harbour. He explains some of the many activities going on in the harbour; fishing boats unloading, tugboats pulling barges, cargo ships, a lighthouse and buoy. They take a ride on the captain’s tugboat.

results.title: Busy hands
results.creator_credit: A Bhaskarrao, M. Bhavnani and Films Division, Government of India
results.brief_description: This film shows villagers as they attend cottage industries classes held in their communities in which families learn weaving, rope making, tailoring, tanning and leather work, pottery and other useful trades. NB: Print unable to be screened due to shrinkage.
